Content-type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1; format=flowed
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT

If you know java you can use the heritrix WARCWriter.

I did some testing with writing filesystem content to ARC files with the heritrix ARCWriter - that was easy programmatically - but required 
som thought because the ARC format is quite restricted to web content - so that might be easier in WARC.

My experiences with writing files to ARC can be found in this paper:
http://netarkivet.dk/publikationer/IntegrationOfNonHarvestedData.pdf

best
-- 
Bjarne Andersen

raffaele messuti wrote:
> 
> 
> Hi,
> i've just read the last warc 0.18 draft
> 
> on warc record type, i see:
> 
> 6.4'resource'
> A 'resource' record contains a resource, without full protocol
> response information.
> For example: a file directly retrieved from a locally accessible
> repository, or the
> result of a networked retrieval where the protocol information has
> been discarded.
> The exact contents of a 'resource' record are determinerecord type
> but also by the URI
> scheme of the record's target-URI, as described below.
> 
> question: with heritrix2 is possible to crawl local files?
> (with file://___ uri?)
> 
> otherwise, do you known working tools to build warcs from
> filesystem available files?
> sure that can be done with warc-tools C library,
> but i don't known C lang
> 
> greets
>
